div1.head:
Richmond Dispatch
by Cowardin & Hammersley.
div1.p:
the Daily Dispatch is served to subscribers at Six and A Quarter Cents Per Week, payable to the Carrier weekly.
Price for mailing, $4 a year, or $2.50 for six months, in advance.
the Semi-Weekly Dispatch is issued every Tuesday and Friday at $2.00, in advance.
the Weekly Dispatch is issued every Friday, and mailed to subscribers at $1 per annum.
Advertisements published until forbid, will be charged 50 cents per square of eight lines for the first insertion, and 25 cents for each continuance

div3.head: Proclamation by the President
div3.p: of the Confederate States of America.--The Senate and House of Representatives of the Confederate States of America have signified their desire that a day may be recommended to the people, to be set apart and observed as a day of humiliation, fasting, and prayer, in the language following, to wit:

q.p: "Reverently recognizing the Providence of God on the affairs of man, and gratefully remembering he guidance, support and deliverance granted to for Patriot Fathers in the memorable war which resulted in the Independence of the American Colonies, and now reposing in Him our supreme confidence and hope in the present struggle for Civil and Religious Freedom, and for the right to live under a Government of our own choice, and deeply impressed with the conviction that without Him nothing is strong, nothing wise, and nothing enlarging in order that the people of this Confederacy may have the opportunity at the same time of offering their adoration to the great Sovereign of the Universe, of penitently confessing their sins and strengthening their vows and purposes of amendment in humble reliance upon His Gracious and Almighty power:

"The Congress of the Confederate States do resolve, That it be recommended to the people of these States that Friday, the 8th day of April next, be set apart and observed as a day of Humiliation, Fasting and Prayer, that Almighty God would so preside over our public counsels and authorities, that He would so inspire our armies and their leaders with wisdom, courage and perseverance, and so manifest Himself in the greatness of His goodness and majesty of His power, that we may be safely and successfully led through the chastening to which we are being subjected to the attainment of an honorable peace, so that while we enjoy the blessings of a free and happy Government, we may ascribe to Him the honor and the glory of our independence and prosperity."

bibl.n: The Senate and House of Representatives of the Confederate States of America

div3.p:
A recommendation so congenial to the feelings of the people will receive their hearty concurrence; and it is a grateful duty to the Executive to unite with their representatives in inviting them to meet in the Courts of the Most High.
Recent events awaken fresh gratitude to the Supreme Ruler of nations.
Our enemies have suffered repeated defeats, and a nefarious scheme to burn and plunder our Capital, and to destroy our civil Government by putting to death the chosen servants of the people, has been baffled and set at naught.
Our armies have been strengthened; our finances promise rapid progress to a satisfactory condition, and our whole country is animated with a hopeful spirit and a fixed determination to achieve independence.

In these circumstances it becomes us, with thankful hearts, to bow ourselves before the throne of the Most High, and while gratefully acknowledging so many mercies, confess that our sins as a people have justly exposed us to His chastisement.
Lot us recognize the sufferings which we have been called upon to endure, as administered by a fatherly hand for our improvement, and with resolute courage and patient endurance let us wait on Him for our deliverance.

In furtherance of these objects, now, therefore, I Jefferson Davis, President of the Confederate States of America, do issue this my Proclamation, calling upon the people of the said States, in conformity with the desire expressed by their representatives, to set apart Friday, the 8th day of April, as a day of Humiliation, Fasting and Prayer, and I do hereby invite them on that day to repair to their several places of public worship and beseech Almighty God to "preside over our public counsels and so inspire our armies and leaders with wisdom, courage, and perseverance; and so to manifest Himself in the greatness of His goodness and in the majesty of His power, that we may secure the blessings of an honorable peace and of free government; and that we, as a people, may ascribe all to the honor and glory of His name."

Given under my hand and the seal of the Confederate States of America, at the city of Richmond, on this 12th day of March, in the year of our Lord one thousand eight hundred and sixty-four.
Jefferson Davis.
div3.closer:
By the President:
J. P. Benjamin,
Secretary of State. mh 14--dtd

div3.head: Office Va. Iron Manufacturing Co, Richmond, Va., March 23, 1864.
div3.p: All persons holding bonds for negro hire and other claims against this company are hereby notified that if the same are not presented at the officer of this company before the

closer.signed: Pres't and Agent V I M Co.

div3.head: Twenty dollars reward.
div3.p:
--Ran away from my house, on the 9th of March, a negro Woman, named Malit's, about fifty years old, black, a little stooped, rather low. She belongs to the estate of James B Jordan, of Goochland, and hired from T J Jordan, his administrator.
She is lurking about the lower end of Goochland, her old neighborhood, or Dover Pits, where her husband is hired.
I will give the above reward if delivered to me, on 4th st., between Duval and Baker, or lodged in jail in Richmond.

div3.head: Ranaway.
div3.p:
--From the gravel train on Sunday, 28th ult, four negroes, named Ned, Frederick, Efford, and Albert, hired of Mrs. A C Isbell, of Cumberland county.
Efford and Albert are of a bright gingerbread color, 5 feet 10 inches high; Ned and Frederick are of dark complexion, stout, 5 feet 7 inches high.
The usual reward will be paid for their apprehension.
div3.closer:
C G Talcott,
Supt. Richmond and Danville R R. mh 8--ts

div3.p:
C B Wellborn.
J A Tay E. Ira E Foster.
J I Queen
Wellborn, Taylor & Co,
General Auction and Comm'n Merchants,
Real Estate and Negro Brokers,
Kile's Building,
Corner Peachtree and Marietta Streets,
Atlanta, Ga.
Consignments solicited.
Goods bought and sold on commission.

div3.head: Change in the Adjutant General's department.
div3.p: There has, we learn, been a division in the duties of the office of Adjutant and Inspector General. Col. Chilton, A. A. G., has been promoted to the flank of Brigadier General and made Inspector General, and Gen. Cooper remains Adjutant General.

div3.head: Some Reflections on the result of Sherman's expedition.
div3.byline: [Translated from the Courier Francais, published in New Orleans.]
div3.p:
In commenting upon the remarks of the True Delta on the gigantic incursion on of Gen. Sherman, and in alluding to that passage of the article in which our cotemporary of St.
Charles street says that. "this expedition has caused the whole Confederacy to shake in its shoes," the Picayune writes the following:

q.p:
"We must no doubt make allowance for enthusiasm in the foregoing report.
The fact of having shaken the whole Confederacy in its shoes, is in direct contradiction of that other report, that the whole Confederacy has had no shoes for three years past.
As to the convey of wagons, fifteen miles long, and having but 1,200 mules, we shall wait for Gen. Sherman's official report on this subject.
We find it difficult to understand how such rich spoils can be taken from the rebels, who have nothing."

div3.p:
This fine irony of the Picayune, it must be confessed, is in its proper place.
The time has arrived to put a stop to such ridiculous trash, that has proved false a thousand times, and yet is always repeated about the Confederacy, its exhaustion, its want of arms, ammunition, or food, and numberless desertion.

What can such writers expect to gain by these miserable, worn out means?
Whom do they propose to deceive?
the people of the North?
They read the opposition papers, by which they learn the true facts.
Europe? But at all points of the scenes of war the press has its correspondents, who are well informed, and who do prompt justice to all such foolery.

Do they expect to discourage by these absurd reports those who have until now shown their devotion to the Southern cause, even in its darkest days?
But this would be to forget the chivalrous feeling of which the Confederacy have given such abundant proof during the past three years. This feeling, this devotion, has not failed once, it seems, on the contrary, to be revived by reverses, and to become purified by fire.

If there are men ready to desert causes that seem to be in peril, there are others, (and it is often the majority, be it said to the honor of humanity,) who press more closely near their flag when threatened by superior numbers.
For them the country is a mother, and men do not desert their mother, even when they know that they must fall with her in a hopeless defence.
To expect to disarm soldiers respected even by their enemies, by talking to them of the relative weakness of those who remain true to their cause, is to ignore the highest, the noblest, the most consoling trait of human nature.
It is to ignore patriotism No!
It is unbecoming the dignity of the press to degrade itself by such inventions.
Its mission is more grave and serious.
It is the duty of the press, especially at such critical times as these, to tell the truth, the whole truth, bitter as it may be. Men who are not wholly deprived of sense, sooner or later tear the well under which it is attempted to conceal it. In spite of all that may be said by writers who are either blind or in had faith, the Confederacy is standing yet. She still has her legs.
We do not know it she still has shoes to cover her feet.
But at all events, judging from the enthusiasm of her soldiers, we believe that her bare feet would be ready, as in the past, for the hardest marches — Her soldiers, if wanting shoes, would no doubt repeat the noble and touching words of a veteran of the first French revolution.
One of his comrades; a conscript, was complaining of the rocks on the road, and showing his bleeding feet. --"When shall we get shoes?" said he. "The proclamation of the General promises laurels," said the veteran, "it says nothing of shoes."

If some of the readers of the True Della have given credence to that pretended poverty of the Confederacy, a poverty verging towards famine; about to devour each other, they must have be a undeceived by the very report of our contemporary which has been so deservedly ridiculed by the Picayune.

This reduced Confederacy must be still rich indeed, if in the small circle which he has overrun, as says the True Della, Sherman has been able to capture such splendid spoils a precious convey fifteen miles long!
If in a distance of ten miles, from Meridian to a point not named, the Confederate States had such Immense wealth, we must conclude that the balance of her resources in other portions of her vast territory must be of some importance.
It is idle, it is dangerous to be misled in the strength of one's enemy.
Better to exaggerate than to lessen it. In knowing the truth one is better prepared for the fight, and if successful, one may really be proud of success after meeting an enemy whose strength is real and acknowledged.

If all that has been said of the Confederates were true, we would be forced to the conclusion that the United States are very weak indeed, when with a large navy, open ports, full granaries, ranks well filled and incessantly replenished by immigration, with soldiers well fed, well clad, well armed, they have been unable to conquer an enemy without a navy, shut out of the world by blockade, furnished, with a comparatively small army, without clothing, and having but half rations on their best days.
The struggle in such conditions would be a source of shame for the North, of eternal glory for the South.

The Federal papers disgrace their own army by obstinately repeating the idle tales to which we refer.
Better admit stoutly and honestly that the enemy is powerful and redoubtable against whom are sent twenty-four thousand infantry and ten or twelve thousand cavalry for a simple incursion, however gigantic that incursion may be.

Mr. Lincoln, who occupies an excellent position to see the varied and interminable spectacle of this war, does not share the Illusions of the optimists of the press.
He does not smile at the blood that flows.
He finds that, though starved, the Confederates fight well indeed.
Hungry as they are, and with empty stomachs, if they offer such resistance what will they be capable of when their stomachs are full?

At all events, starved or not, what remains of the Confederacy is a sufficient cause of unbusiness to the President of the American Union.
He does not indulge in the dreams of newspaper editors of the school of the True Della and others, and in order to make sure of defeating the soldiers of the South the new Xerxes looks for new guaranties, After the abundant harvests of men that he has gathered he calls for more; and what a call!
five hundred thousand soldiers!
And at what time has he recourse to such measure?
At the time when his army has so mained the manufactories that the few workmen who have remained at home feet their strength, and strike for higher wages; at a time when the people, who have risen once already, still complain and murmur against these renewed calls; at a time when the human harvest failing at home, recourse must be had to foreign enrollments at fabulous prices and bounties.

In whatever cause our sympathies and convictions may be enlisted, let us look the situation in the face.
The Confederacy has not received a single mortal would.
She has been struck some serious blows, but she seems to rise from these attacks with more ardor and more life than ever.

The United States, on the other hand, after this long and costly war of three years, seem determined, still more than at the start, to carry it on, until their adversary shall succumb — for it cannot be brought to submit — and in order to attain their end they call forth their incalculable resources.--The truth is that we have arrived at an hour of frightful crisis, that the "gigantic invasion" of Sherman, whether it is a success or a failure, is but a prelude to enormous battles — to supreme battles, perhaps — that on both sides everything is ready, powerful, that these battalions, reinforced in immense proportions, are about to such against each other with fury and implacable hatred in their hearts, and that this tremendous shock will not only shake the Confederacy in her shoes (since she appears to have shoes) but also this whole continent.
The campaign which is about to open will bring events of unknown grandeur, perhaps, and a sacrifice of lives without precedent.
Too much blood has flowed already: and Europe, tired of waiting for the issue which is constantly promised, might well say one of these days — Enough!

div3.head: Money and patriotism.
div3.p:
--The Columbia (S. C.) Southern Guardian, of the 18th, commences the publication of a series of letters giving an account of matters and things in Knoxville, Tennessee.
The writer is a clergyman, who has been driven from his home for his devotion to the South and has taken refuge with his family in Columbia.--Speaking of Knoxville, after its occupation by the Federal forces, he says:

q.p:
There are some men whom we can always confide in; men whom danger, calamity, threats of tyrants commanding wrong, only press closer to our side; but, alas!
how few. When friendship is to be maintained at the expense of jeopardy to property, to reputation, to life, then we are furnished with the test and measure of its strength.
I saw many in Knoxville tried in this furnace, and they came out of the fire unscathed; and I thank God my faith in my kind is established.
But the wretched, drivelling money makers in Knoxville I found unfaithful to friend, to country, and to God.
This is a lesson for those who will learn.
I know no one in Knoxville who has made a fortune during this war who has not, to save that fortune, become a Judas.
We cannot serve God or country and Mammon,

div3.head: Two extracts from revolutionary History.
div3.p:
The war carried on by Great Britain against the colonies during the Revolution was waged for subjugation.
The present war, waged by the Yankees against independent States, is for the same object.
The original manuscript order book of Lord Cornwallis is in the possession of a gentleman near Fayetteville, N. C., and the following extracts from it are published to show the difference between the conduct of the Commanding Generals of the British army in the seventeenth and the Yankee army in the nineteenth centuries:

div4.p:
Orders--Lord Cornwallis is highly displeased that several houses were set on fire during the march this day — a disgrace to the army — and that he will punish with the utmost severity any person or persons who shall be found guilty of committing so disgraceful an outrage.
His lordship requests the commanding officers of corps will endeavor to find out the persons who set fire to the houses this day.

It is with great concern that Lord Cornwallis acquaints the army that he has lately received the most shocking complaints of the excesses committed by the troops.
He calls in the most serious manner on the officers commanding brigades and corps to put a stop to this , which must inevitably bring disgrace and ruin on His Majesty's service.
He is convinced that it is in their power to prevent it, and has seen so many proofs of their zeal for the service of their country that he cannot doubt of their exertions to defeat and punish offenders; without which the blood of the brave and deserving soldiers will be shed in vain, and it will not be even in the power of victory to give success.

Great complaints having been made of negroes straggling from the line of march, plundering and using violence to the inhabitants, it is Lord Corn wallis's positive orders that no negro shall be suffered to carry arms on any pretence, and all officers and other persons who employ negroes are desired to acquaint them that the Provost Marshal has received orders to seize and punish on the spot any negro following the army who may offend against this regulation.

Lord Cornwallis is very sorry to be again obliged to call the attention of the officers of the Army to the repeated orders against plundering.
He desires that the orders given on the 28th January, 4th February, and the 16th February, may be read at the head of each troop and company on each of the three first halting days, and he assures the officers, that if their duty to their King and country, and their feelings for humanity, are not sufficient to enforce their obedience to them, he must, however reluctant, make use of such power as the military laws have placed in his hands.
A foraging party, consisting of one officer, two sergeants, two corporals, and twenty-four privates, to assemble at the guns this morning at 8 o'clock with the battalion horses.

Notwithstanding every order, every entreaty, that Lord Cornwallis has given to the army to prevent the shameful practice of plundering and distressing the country, and those orders backed by every effort that can have been made by Brigadier General O'Hara, he is shocked to find this evil still prevails and ashamed to observe that the frequent complaints he receives from headquarters of the irregularity of the guards particularly affects the credit of this corps.
He therefore calls upon the officers, non-commissioned officers, and those men who are yet possessed of the feelings of humanity and actuated by the best principles of soldiers, the love of their country, the good of the service, and the honor of their own corps, to assist with the same indefatigable diligence the General himself is determined to persevere in, in order to detect and punish all men and women so offending with the utmost severity and example.

The General is convinced the exertions of the officers alone will not so immediately bring about this reformation as requisite, but he trusts he may have the greatest dependence on the assistance of the non commissioned officers and every good soldier, many of whom he knows are above these practices.
The General has wished not to trouble the men with too many frequent roll-calls, but he is sorry to find his intentions are frustrated by their irregularity, and is therefore obliged to order the most frequent roll-calls, and that all men absent therefrom shall be deemed disobedient of orders, tried and punished before the company on the spot.
Women to attend all roll-calls in the rear of the such as are in the service of brigade.
The Commandants are desired to proceed to the trial of those men offending yesterday, and to put the sentence of the Court-Martial in execution immediately, in the presence of all the officers.
N B.--The women to attend all punishments.

The following extracts from Tarleton's Campaigns (p. 290) relates to the last official duty performed by Lord Cornwallis within our borders, and is in keeping with all we know of his previous course.
Tarleton was always spoken of as "the cruel" and frequently "the bloody Tarleton;" most unjustly, however, if the mildest modern Northern Generals in the departments of Virginia and North Carolina be selected as a standard of comparison.
More property in point of value was destroyed by the raiders between Washington and Rocky Mount than by Lord Cornwallis in his three months campaign, traversing the State in two different directions, and marching upwards of 600 miles:

q.p:
On the arrival of some country people, Earl Cornwallis directed Lt. Col. Tarleton to dismount his dragoons and mounted infantry, and to form them into a rank entire, for the convenient inspection of the inhabitants, and to facilitate the discovery of the villains who had committed atrocious outrages the preceding evening.
A sergeant and one private dragoon were pointed out and accused of rape and robbery.
They were conducted to Halifax, where they were condemned to death by martial law. The immediate infliction of the sentence exhibited to the army and manifested to the country the discipline and justice of the British General.

div4.p: This example was rendered more imposing by the fact, that Col. Tarleton's legion had advanced four miles beyond Halifax, when the miscreants were detected, and the legion required to return.--The whole army was delayed an entire day, in order to carry out the sentence of the Court Martial.

div3.head: Unique description of a work of art.
div3.p: --The Charleston Mercury has the following description of a work of art, which will be recognized as formerly on exhibition in Richmond:

q.p:
While looking over some memoranda in an old pocket book, yesterday afternoon, our search was interrupted in a most agreeable manner by the appearance of an old piece of art, a relic of former days — days when war was not spoken of, and when it was not supposed the people of the two sections would ever try to their blue cotton umbrellas down each other's throats — at long law. It is of a metallic substance and circular inform.
Upon one side is the raised figure of a beautiful woman, who is seated upon an old shovel, the handle of which has been broken out. She is evidently in the act of putting on her hose, and has in her right hand a garter, when her attention is attracted to the noise of footsteps behind.--Her attitude betokens this, as the hand is thrown around, and her look backward is one of painful anxiety.
In her left hand she carries a staff, upon the upper end of which is wrapped a dirty towel.--At her feet, between two arrow heads, are the numbers--1, 8, 5, 3.
Surrounding the whole are a lot of devices made up of triangles, placed one upon the other.
Upon the garter which the female holds in her right hand, is the name of the who executed this singular and almost forgotten piece.
His name is L. I Berty, and he once enjoyed a reputation world wide.

div3.p:
The reverse side of the relic shows a wreath, which is surrounded by words that time and circumstances have entirely obliterated.
Within the wreath there is also an inscription, the mention of which we forbear, as we do not wish to barrow unpleasant recollections.
It is a beautiful piece of art, and in former years the possessor of a copy of it was accounted a great man, without regard to merits of head or heart.
The copies are now becoming so very scarce that some of our best citizens are daily jeopardizing their souls in order to make a large collection of them.

div3.head: The sentiment of Europe.
div3.p:
--The Hon L. Q. C. Lamar, of Mississippi, delivered an address in Milledgeville, Georgia, a few nights since, on the sentiment of Europe in reference to the Confederate States. Mr. Lamar went to Europe over a year ago, and had good opportunities of ascertaining the tone of European opinion.
He found the intelligent people everywhere candid in expressions of sympathy or the Confederates, and of admiration for the dignity and statesmanship of our rulers, and the valor, endurance, and fortitude of our soldiers and people; but there were considerations of a political character operating to deter any official recognition or intervention by the Governments of Europe.
Still the approval of intelligent European opinion was cheering.
Great Britain was sensitive of any act which should incur the hostility of the United States.
France was deferred by the refusal of other powers to join her.--Russia alone was open in her partiality for the United States.
The ignorant populace of Germany had been beguiled by Northern fanaticism and had sent recruits to the Northern armies.
The Pope has declared our nationality an established fact.--The financiers of London had taken the Confederate loan, while they refused to touch that of the United States, which was a financial recognition of our national existence, and a substantial evidence of their confidence in our success.
Daniel McSweeney, a policeman of Charleston, S. C., was shot and killed by a soldier whom he had arrested, on Friday night last.

div3.head: The gold bill at the North.
div3.p:
Chase's gold bill, which he got through Congress, has not been effective in keeping gold down in New York.
The following predictions from the New York World before its passage have been pretty well verified:

q.p:
Heaven knows we should like to keep the price of gold down.
Mr. Chase's inflated irredeemable paper currency reduced our profits last year by a good many thousand dollars, and we shall be thankful it this year is not worse.
If the gold bill would keep down the price of gold it would certainly be for our interest to urge its passage.
But it will not keep down the price of gold, and if the bill passes our reasoning will soon enough find abundant confirmation in the fact.

div3.p:
On the gold reserve depends at last the credit of the nation.
It is the one prop left.
Other props Mr. Chase and his co-laborers have knocked away.
It is the grossest violation of public faith with the nation's creditors to knock away this prop also.
It encourages a financial immorality which will teach the people the shameful lesson of repudiation.

But if it is useless in these times to preach strict financial morals, let us repeat, that the gold bill will not accomplish what those who east patriotic votes for it hope it will accomplish.
The purposes of members who sold gold and then voted for the gold bill, and who will so vote again it doubtless may accomplish.
It will put down the price temporarily.
But the measure of its depression will be less than the measure of its lavation when Mr. Chase comes to want the gold again.
What he may gain now he must lose then, and we reiterate that with our present debt, to say nothing of its enormous rate of increase, Mr. Chase has not had, has not now, and will not have, any too much cold to discharge the obligations of the Government.

There is but one way to reduce the price of gold permanently.
Its value is stable, of course, depending on cost of production, the price-fluctuations rising above or falling below that exact mark, with the instability of supply and demand perpetually adjusting themselves to an equilibrium.
To reduce the price of gold is to say, raise the price of the paper, which, except in California, Mr. Chase has made his financial yard stick.
And since the cost of production of an inconvertible paper currency is practically nothing, and its value must depend more exclusively than ever upon its supply, after the issue of enough to displace specie and the convertible currency, to raise the price of green-backs, diminish the supply of green backs.
Then gold will tall, and not till then.
But no; Mr. Chase is pouring out new issues, and more are yet to come.
Congress potters over such financial fiddle fiddled as the gold bill, and never looks to the sluices which the Secretary guards.
Gold will rise — that is, legal render money will fall — in value; a paper dollar will soon be worth less than fifty pennies, and there will be politicians like Greeley who will make fools like his followers believe that speculation makes the difference between Chase's paper and nature's gold; that with fresh issues of legal tender the premium on gold can be slightly "reduced," and the nation will pay as the bitter price of its fully is electing fanatics to power not only the billions in which we reckon the cost of the war which they conspired with Southern fanatics to rekindle, but also still other billions, of which the Government is depriving the laboring classes exclusively, by a daily, constant, impoverishing drain.

div3.head: Barbarities of Tories in Tennessee
div3.p: --A letter from Marshall, N. C., to the Raleigh Confederate dated the 6th inst., gives the following account of a massacre at Indian'creek, Tennessee:

q.p:
Lieut. Duyck, with some twelve or fourteen men, were sent to Indian Creek, Tenn., and stationed as Presley Blankenship's house.
They had been there but a few days when on last.
Wednesday, Major Rirk, (Federal,) commanding 1st N. C. regiment, (tories,) consisting of men from this immediate country, together with Laurell men, dashed upon Lieut. Duyck, killing one and capturing four prisoners. Duyck himself escaped.--They shot the prisoners upon the spot, viz: Marion Kamsey, Reuben Woodard, Coleman Justice, and a man by the name of Sullivan.
After they killed the prisoners they strippen them.
One man (Woodard) struggled an hour or two, and they placed a gun against his head in the presence of his father, an old man, and blew his brains out.--They then proceeded to Blankenship's house and murdered him and his son, who were not soldiers.
They then took his horses and put them in his wagon, or rather hitched them to it, and loaded his wagon out of his house, and drove his cows off from his children.
Lieut. Duyck belongs to the 64th N. C. troops.

bibl.n: A letter from Marshall, N. C

div3.head: Army Amusements.
div3.p:
--A correspondent of the Mobile Advertiser has recently been to Johnston's Army.
He writes back:

q.p:
The enemy having prudently retired upon my in our "kum outer that biled short, you Quotesmaster's clurk, you!" Respectfully declined the invitation, and was derisively apostrophized in the name of Longhome "Hey- oh, Longhome!" Thereupon I assumed an expression of court mardal, and gazed sternly upon the interlocutors.
This provoked a laugh, the laugh set fire to a shout, and broke out into a yell two or three regiments in length. "He's chawed," suggested one creature with no sent to his pantaloons--"he's chawed — his face's red." If a modest man could run such a gauntlet of merciless criticism without a red face, he must be a man of muscle of brass.

bibl.n: A correspondent of the Mobile Advertiser

div3.head: Death of an Irish Pass.
div3.p:
--Francis William Canfield, 2d Earl of Charlemont, died recently at Clontarf, in Ireland, aged 83 years. His father gained great celebrity in the last century as the leader in the Irish volunteer movement in 1779 and 1782, and as one of the most active promoters of Irish legislative independence, and figures largely in the lives of Burke, Fox, Pitt, and Gratten.
The late peer was an amiable gentleman, holding rather extreme liberal opinions but always the steady supporter of the Whig . Of late years he has been an object of interest as the "father" of the House of Lords, of which he has been a member since 1806, and the survivor of the old irish Parliament.
He was a member of the Irish House of Commons from 1795 1799, when he succeeded to the peerage and in the House of Lords in Dubith till the Union of 1861.
He received the ribbon of the order of St. Patrick in 1831.

div3.head: Sad case
div3.p:
--Ellen Welch was recently fined five dollars and committed to Bridewell for ninety days, in Chicago, for drunkenness and vagrancy.
The Chicago Journal says that she is the since of Daniel "Connell, the daughter of his sister, Mary O'Connell — and that she could claim as her father the lord of Kearney Castle.
She eloped with a young officer, and the couple came to Philadelphia, where they resided one year, when her husband died." The widow came to Chicago, married again, lost her husband, got into disreputable company, and went from bad to worse, until she brought up in a police court.

--Yankees Deserting.--The latest news from Florida is not very favorable to the discipline and integrity of the Yankee army under Seymour.
A dispatch from the operator at Baldwin, dated 17th, says: "The news from the front this morning is that eighty-five Yankee deserters came in early this morning, and they report that forty more are on the way." The operator at Waldo reports that the Yankees at Palatka are also deserting fast.--About fifty had skedaddled from their lines, and negro pickets are stationed in every direction to keep the clan of robbers together.--Savannah Republican.

div3.head: The Vallandigham fund.
div3.p:
--A fund is being raised in Ohio, called the Vallandigham fund.
A lady enclosing a $50 subscription to Gov. Medary, of the Crisis, accompanies it with the following: "For refusing to speak by permission of and within the limits of Order No. 38, signed by Ambrose Burnside, and choosing to speak by authority, as he expressed it, of Order.
No. 1, the Constitution of the United States, signed by George Washington, Mr. Vallandigham is banished from his home and country.
We yet hope he may return and receive the highest honors of the Republic."

div3.head: The Presidency in West Virginia.
div3.p:
--A meeting in West Virginia has declared for Chase.
One of the resolutions says: "We believe either Hon. S. P. Chase, Major Gen. Fremont, Major Gen. Butler, Major Gen. Banks, or Major Gen. Grant to be far preferable as a Presidential candidate to Mr. Lincoln; but our Judgment is in favor of a civilian rather than a soldier." Another of the series declares explicitly for Chase.

div3.head: Dead.
div3.p:
--Dr. H. S. LeVert, a prominent citizen of Mobile, Ala., died on the 16th inst. He was born in King William county, Virginia, in the year 1834.
His father came over to America as Fleet Surgeon with Gen. Lafayette, and his mother was the niece of Admiral Vernon.
He graduated in Philadelphia in 1828, and in 1829 settled in Mobile for the practice of his profession.

div3.head: North Carolina.
div3.p:
--The Tarboro' Southerner, of the 19th, says that everything appears quiet about Washington and Plymouth.
Persons who have been down in that country report that the Yankees have been certainly reinforced at both places.

div3.head: Tons of Greenbacks.
div3.p:
--Eight tons of greenback's were carried over the New Jersey railroad to Washington one day last week.
The money is said to be the collections of different Internal Revenue officers.

When old Baggs, the model of punctuality, came to die he called off a list of those persons whom he wished to act us pall bearers.
After a few moments he spoke again. "My son, read me that list; is Mr. Wiggins's name on it?" "Yes, father, it is." "Then," said the old man, "strike it off; he is never punctual, never anywhere in season, and he might detain the procession an hour."
Mrs. Nancy Hawkins, of Shelby county, N. C., committed suicide by hanging herself last week.

div3.head: Garroted and robbed.
div3.p:
--Mr. D. Schonfeld was garroted and robbed of five thousand two hundred dollars, on Thursday evening, under the following circumstances; On Thursday morning, as he was coming out of a broker's establishment, he was accosted by a man whom he had frequently seen standing about the street corners, who inquired if he wanted to buy some gold, telling him he had two hundred in gold which he would sell him for twenty for one.
Schonfeld said he would like to buy the gold, but that he did not have the necessary funds about him. After some further talk it was agreed that the parties should meet at the Spotswood corner, at 7 o'clock P. M., where Schonfeld would accompany the man to his house, on Gamble's hill, and conclude the purchase of the gold.
Both were punctual to their appointment, and immediately started for Gamble's hill.
When on 3d street, just in front of the residence of Mr. Jos. Mayo, two men who Schonfeld had noticed for some time walking behind him, closed in on him, and one of them threw a bag over his head and drew it tight round his neck, whilst the other, and the man from whom he was to have bought the gold, held his arms and took from his pocket a roll of notes amounting to five thousand two hundred dollars. Having effected their object, the three robbers ran off, leaving the bag over Schonfeld's head.
In their haste they overlooked Mr. Schonfield's watch and another roll of money of a thousand dollars which he had in another pocket.
No arrests have been made.

div3.head: Commissioners of the Revenue and Justices of the Peace.
div3.p: --The Governor, we understand, upon reconsideration of the propriety of exempting Commissioners of the Revenue, finding that there are many duties incumbent upon them besides the assessment of the revenue, has come to the conclusion that it is necessary to the State Government that they should be exempted, and he will certify to them accordingly.

In reference to Justices of the Peace he declines certifying in favor of their exemption when they are under 40 years of age, being satisfied that persons above forty-five can easily be found competent to the performance of the magisterial duties.

div3.head: Supplies for the poor.
div3.p:
--In a paragraph in the local department of this paper on yesterday credit was awarded to Mr. Lewis D. Crenshaw for supplies of breadstuffs to the poor at reduced prices.
We are requested by Mr. Crenshaw to state that whatever has been done by him in this way has been equally shared by his partner, Mr. Haxall, the breadstuffs alluded to being supplied by the firm of Haxall & Crenshaw. While according to those through whose instrumentality the statement was made the kindest intentions, he regrets the publicly given to it, and feels that more credit is given in it than is deserved.
Thus much at Mr. C.'s request.
We will add, since the matter has appeared in the newspaper, that the liberality and timely charities of Haxall & Crenshaw entitle that firm to a prominent place amongst those who deserve to be held in grateful remembrance for their deeds during this trying period of war.

div3.head: Mayor's Court.
div3.p:
--The most important matter before this Court yesterday, was a case of garroting Daniel Garey, a marine, charged two other marines, Patrick Stack and James Rollins, with assaulting him in the street, and robbing him of $500. He stated that on Tuesday evening about eight o'clock, after taking three or four drinks with the accused, in the bar-room of one Beckman, on Main street, near the corner of 17th street, he started alone to go down 17th street to Cary.
When he had gone about fifty yards, Stack ran up behind him, and seized him round the neck, and Rollins coming up, thrust his hand into his pocket and took out a roll of notes amounting to five hundred firm, us to the same company with them, and knew them well.--A watchman testified that Garey had come to the watch house Tuesday night about eight o'clock, and complained that he had been robbed by a man named Stack and a sergeant of marines.
The defence introduced witnesses to prove that Garey came down to the marine quarters about ten o'clock Tuesday night, very much intoxicated, and demanding to know who were absent from the quarters, and when he learned that sergeant Rollins and corporal Stack were, he wrote down their names, and said he would send them to the penitentiary.
An important witness being absent, the Mayor continued the case till this morning.
Mahala, a free negro from West Tennessee, was committed to jail for want of free papers.
Washington Johnson, free negro, was ordered twenty-five lashes for stealing a hen from Mr. Carey Nicholas.

div3.head: Judge Lyons's Court.
div3.p: --Jas. M. D, Irvin was tried for obtaining one hundred and one dollars from Captain Waytt, C. S. Paymaster, on forged commutation papers, and the jury having heard the evidence he was acquitted.

div3.head: Folks Arrest.
div3.p: --Martha, slave of Mrs. S. Bagnan, was arrested yesterday evening and locked up in the cage for using insulting language to Mr. Thomas C. Epps.

div3.head: Castle Thunder and the Libby.
div3.p: --These institutions afforded not a single item yesterday.

from Norfolk and Portsmouth will find at the Confederate Reading Room a late of the Old Hominion, published at Norfolk, containing much news of local affairs in Norfolk and Portsmouth, and matters interesting to them — just received this morning.
Late United States papers received at the Confederate Reading Room by every flag of truce.

argument.p: Entered according to act of Congress in the year 1863, by J. S. Thrasher, in the Clerk's office of the District Court of the Confederate States for the Northern District of Georgia.

div3.head: From Northern Virginia.
div3.p: --The snow is fast melting away, but the roads fire quite deep in mud. All quiet in front and in our lines.
Governor Vance, of N. C., is expected to visit the army to-morrow.

div4.head: [Second Dispatch.]
div4.p:
--A heavy rain is falling here.
Gov. Vance, of N. C., arrived here to day, and is the guest of Gen. Daniel.

figure.figDesc: Page image of Daily Dispatch, Volume 26, Number 74, page 2.

div3.head: The Irish.
div3.p:
What effect the enormous Federal bounties offered to Irish soldiers may have in tempting more of that hitherto misguided people into the ranks of our enemies it is impossible to determine.
But it is clear that very great inducements must be offered to prevail upon any considerable number of them to enter a service where so many thousands of Irishmen have only attained a bloody grave.
It is reported — and we are inclined to believe the report — that the Irish of the North are becoming generally disaffected to the war, and that the influence of their clergy is exerted in conformity with the pacific and Christian counsels of the Pope.
The Irish have always been the best soldiers in the Federal armies, and the absence of this fighting element from future battles would render the enemy less formidable than at any former period of the war. They may substitute negroes, but they will only excite our dericion; or they may ransack the Old Word for mercenaries to do the fighting of a nation which is afraid to fight for itself, but a people who have encountered and defeated Irishmen have no reason to fear any other human foe.

The Irish ought to be with the Confederacy, because it was the South which resened them from the political and religious persecutions which the North had organized against them a few years ago, because it is only in Southern independence that they can look for a refuge from the same persecutions, which will be revived against them when this war is ended as inevitably as the rising of to-morrow's sun. Puritanism would cease to be Puritanism if it had not a victim.
And its whole history attests that, of all its victims, there is none which it so loves to hunt, and worry and devour as the religious faith of Ireland.
Anti slavery is a mere episode; detestation of Catholicism is its whole existence; its mother's milk, its blood, marrow, muscle and bones.
Every Irishman knows that, from the hour of Cromwell's horrible excesses in Ireland, to the present moment, the religion that the Irishman loves above all things, the Puritahates above all things, and desires above all things to degrade and destroy.
Nothing keeps this appetite now in abeyance but the progress of this war. Even that is not sufficient to suppress altogether the vindictive animosity awakened by the Pope's late letter, a manifestation of Christian and friendly regard to a struggling and heroic people which the Puritans of the North will never forgive.
And do not the Irish perceive that Puritanism is now the Master of the North?
There was a time when this could not be said.
There was a time when, in the middle and some of the Western States of the United States, it was almost as common to sneer at Puritanism as in the South.
There was a time, even at the beginning of the war when the sentiment of nationality and idolatry of the Union, was the dominant idea of the Northern mind.
But what has become of Unionism?
Where is Conservatism?
The man in the United States who utters these words makes himself a laughing stock.
The Conservatives and the Democrat, with their liberal political and religious ideas, area weak and helpless minority, and Puritanism, armed to the teeth, with its foot upon the prostrate laws and liberties of the hand, reigns the supreme master of the nation at Washington, and even drives on Roman Catholic Irishmen to fight its battles and perish in its slaughter pens.
Will it be more mindful of their religious than it has been of their political rights, when it has the opportunity of glutting its innate and ineradicable hatred of the Roman Catholic religious.
Let the Irishmen of the North take warning in time.
The Confederacy once conquered and such flames of religious persecution will be kindled in the North as the world has not beheld for centuries.
If the Puritans are capable of visiting such horrors as they are now visiting upon a kindred and Protestant people, what are they not capable of visiting upon Roman Catholic Irishmen?
But if Puritanism fails in this struggle, as to all human appearances it will fail, it becomes thenceforth as impotent as it is malignant; the North itself will turn upon and crush it as the author of its ruin; it will perish politically and ecclesiastically, and the freedom and religion of all mankind will be the better for its perishing.

div3.head: Gen. Grant.
div3.p:
The Yankees must have a military idol.
It is a necessity of their warlike nature.
Nothing short of a Napoleon will satisfy the cravings of their martial souls.
Their inventive genius has long labored to produce a demigod, and successive disappointments have not chilled the ardor of their desire.
At last they flatter themselves they have accomplished their object.
The once frantic devotees of Scott and McClellan are now on their knees to Grant, and rivalling the priests of Beal in the vehemence and madness of their idolatry.

We have no disposition to underrate the military qualities of the new Yankee demigod.
It was a maxim of Napoleon that an equilibrium of brains and courage was essential to the character of a great General — In point of intellect, McClellan is the first man of the Yankee army.
In point of energy, Grant is probably equal to any of their officers.
If the two men could be rolled into one, which is an achievement beyond the power of even Yankee ingenuity, a closer resemblance to a great General would be the result than the Yankees have yet produced in this war. But while McClellan has the brains, he had not the pluck; and while Grant may have the pluck, he has not McClellan's brains.
The miserable failure of his late plan to overrun the Southwest by three columns, explodes forever his pretensions to great military genius.
Whatever he has accomplished has been the result of overwhelming numbers and the weakness and imbecility of our own resistance.
Did he ever defeat a Confederate army except by three to one?
Did he ever meet one of the favorite Confederate Generals on any field, except Beauregard at Shiloh?
and then he and it was not until Buell came that General

div4.p: On Friday morning, 25th, at half-past 2 o'clock, of pneumonia, Johnson Adams, eldest child of Laura A and Johnson Adams, aged 8 years and six months.
The friends and acquaintances of the family, and also the scholars of St. James-Sunday School, are invited to attend his funeral, from St. James Church, on Sunday afternoon, at half-past 3 o'clock.
On Friday, the 25th inst, in the 65th year of her age, Mrs. Sarah Robb, widow of the late Charles C Robb, of Baltimore, Md.

Her funeral will take place on to-morrow, (Sunday,) at 4 o'clock P M, from the residence of her son-in-law, Nathaniel Tyler, corner of Franklin and 2d streets. The friends and acquaintances of the family are invited to attend.
At his residence, on Franklin street, on the 17th of March, Jno. Baxter, in the 36th year of his age.
Mobile, Cincinnati, and Philadelphia papers please copy.
On the morning of the 24th, after a protracted illness, Mr. Fendal G Henrey, in the 42d year of his age.
His remains were taken to Goochland county for interment.

div4.head: Tribute of respect.

opener.dateline:
Headq'rs Army Northern Virginia,
Camp Gen. Lee's Body Guard.

div4.p: At a meeting of the members of company D, Richardson's (39th Virginia) battalion of cavalry, held the 15th day of March, 1864, for the purpose of giving an expression of their feelings relative to the recent death of Lieut R C , of this company.
On motion, Capt W W Page, was called to the Chair and Serg't J Passano appointed Secretary.
After a fitting gy to the lamented deceased, paid in eloquent and appropriate terms by the Chairman.

On motion a committee of three, consisting of Lieut. Thos J McKaig, Serg't J Passano, and Private W F G Ga nett, was appointed to prepare and report resolutions expressive of the pain and deep regret felt by all present with regard to the event they were assembled to commemorate.
The committee after a short retirement, reported the following resolutions, which were unanimously adopted:

q.p: Whereas, it has pleased Almighty God, in His all wise providence, to remove from our midst our loved friend and gallant officer, Lieut R G Temple, of Chesterfield county, Va.: Therefore, be it

div4.p: Resolved, That with sincere sorrow do we mourn the loss of one who, after an intimate association of twelve months, had won our highest respect and confidence as a gentlemen, our warmest admiration as a soldier and patriot.

Resolved, That to the disconsolate mother and bereaved family, we tender our heartfelt sympathies, and may our ever kind and merciful Saviour graciously pour upon their wounded hearts the balm of His tender love and consolation.
Resolved, That a copy of these resolutions be transmitted to the family of Lieut. Temple and be published in the Richmond papers.

div3.head:
Richmond Encampment, no. 2,
Richmond, March 26, 1864.
div3.p:
Orders No. 8.--Sir Knights: Attend a called assembly of your Encampment at the Masons' Hall, on Tuesday evening, the 29th inst, at 6 o'clock, for work and instruction.
Officers will appear in full regalia, with sidearm.
Candidates will be present at 6.30 P M. Transient Sir Knights are respectfully invited to attend.
div3.closer:
By order of the E Commander.
W L Maule, Captain General.
James E Biddick, Recorder. mh 26--3t

div3.head: The two Nations.
div3.p: A Key to the History of the American War. By the author of the First and Second Years of the War.
[From the Charleston Courier.]

Edward A Pollard, the author of a history of the war, of which two volumes (years) have enjoyed a wide circulation, has written in his best and most forcible style, a pamphlet "The Two Nations, a key to the history of the American War," published by Ayres & Wade, Richmond, Va. We suppose it will soon be supplied by booksellers and dealers, and we commend it to general and attentive perusal.
In so doing we do not commit ourselves to the approval of all opinions of the author, or an endorsement of all his conclusions and inferences.
We only wish to greet and hail any and every attempt by any thinker and writer of original vigor, to elevate the tone and plane of political discussions.
Thinking men are tired of the twaddle of petty politicians, who know nothing but platforms of parties or or eds of cliques and caucuses.
Mr. Pollard, like the author of the Atlanta Register's address, and a few others connected more or less actively with the Confederate press, seeks the higher range of thought and survey, and disquisition, which was first asserted in American politics by Calhoun, since the age of our revolutionary statesmen.

To show from the necessary operation of general laws the duality of American institutions, the essential distinctiveness and-vitality of the States, the paramount importance of the States, and impossibility of any permanent and prosperous league or federation otherwise, are leading objects with writers of this elevated school, of which N A Pollard is a prominent representative.

The pamphlet before us contains a graphic and cordially emphatic tribute to Calhoun as a political , whose merits and teachings are only to receive due appreciation and attention.
but, meanwhile, as the pam who wish to study the

div3.head:
Headq'rs Co B, forces local defence,
Richmond, March 26, 1864.
div3.p: Attention.--Member of company B are hereby notified to attend a meeting of the company for the transaction of business, at Monticello Hall, Broad st, on this (Saturday) evening, at 7 ½ o'clock P M.
div3.closer:
By order,
W H Hayward, Capt. mh 28--1t*

div3.head:
Headq'rs 5th Va cavalry,
March 24, 1864.
div3.p: Notice.--The companies of this regiment will assemble at Ashland instead of Meadow Bridge, as heretofore ordered.

div3.head: Military Notice.
div3.p:
--I am allowed by General Orders No. 38 to enlist members between the ages of 17 and 18 and 45 and 50.
A few more names will be taken into my company, (H,) 3d battalion, for local defence, commanded by Major John Henley.
For further particulars apply to
div3.closer:
Capt. A G Babcock,
At Geo. Dunn & Co's.
Rank Note Engravers and Printers,
Corner Main and 14th sts. mh 25--3t*

div3.head: Special Notice.
div3.p: --All the members of company H, 5th Va cavalry, will assemble at Ashland on the 27th inst, without fail.
div3.closer:
By order of W L M Dent,
Commanding company.
Geo C Mountcastle, O S mh 25--3

div3.p: The following named men are deserters from Co G, 25th Va Batt'n. The Government reward of $80 will be paid for the and delivery of any one of them to any Provost Marshal in the Confederate States: Cerg'l H S Hill, Richmond, Va; Private James Byron, Fredericksburg, Va; Private Chas Schick, a German, Richmond, Va; Private Allen Tucker, alias Wigs, Charleston, S C.
div3.closer:
Lucien L Bass,
Capt Com'g Co G, 25th Va. Batt'n.

div3.head: Military Notice.
div3.p:
--My company, (G.) Major Henley's battalion, being in course of reorganization, persons between the ages of 15 and 18 and 45 and 50 are hereby notified of the opportunity now afforded to united themselves with the above named corps.
Those members of the company who have guns or accoutrements in their possession are hereby notified to return them without delay.
div3.closer:
F W Wise, Captain,
Treasurer's office, C S A,
Old Custom-House Building. mh 25--6t

div3.p: 946 acres of James river Load, Negroes, Stock, &c, for sale — Will be sold to the highest bidder, on the promises, without reserve, on Tuesday, the 5th day of April next, my tract of land, containing 916 acres, of which acres is low grounds and about 40 acres of good branch flats, 300 acres wood land and some old field pine; a good brick dwelling house, with six rooms, passage and closets, and all necessary out building, (except a barn and thrashing machine,) which has been recently burnt.) It lies on the north side of the river, 36 miles above Richmond and 6 miles above Goochland Court House; has a very valuable corn mill, running two pairs of stones, a circular saw mill, supplied with water from the canal; between 30 and 40 negroes, men, women, boys and children; household and kitchen furniture; 1 very superior rosewood piano, with Coleman's attachment; I carriage and harness; 1 buggy and harness, as good as new; 1 portable thrashing machine; 1 buckeye reaper and mower; 4 horses, 10 mules, 40 cattle, 12 work oxen, 90 sheep, and 60 hogs; 1 very fine Cotswold ram; about 50 barrels of corn, and all other things on the place.
Terms.--Cash or credit, to suit purchasers.

It is very seldom such valuable property is in market.
There is now seeded on the place 200 bushels winter oats and 130 bushels wheat.
Should the day be too wet to be out, the sale will take place the first good day thereafter.

div4.head: Farm for rent,
div4.p:
negroes for hire, and sale of personal property.--On Wednesday; the 23d inst, the farm whereon Mrs. E A Gregory lately resided, in the country of Chesterfield, near Drewry's Bluff, will be rented at public auction, on the promises, for balance of the year.
Immediately after which the servants thereon will be hired out for the unexpired portion of this year; and at the same time will be sold all of the household and kitchen furniture, farming implements, a good horse, cow, hogs, a lot of nice corn, sheaf oats, fodder and shucks, some cord wood, and contents of ice-house

The accessibility of this place to Richmond, both by the river and railroad several times per day, makes it desirable to a person who might wish to do business in Richmond and at the some time have his family enjoy the benefits of the country.
Postponement.--The above sale has been postponed to Tuesday, the 20th inst, when it will take place if the day is suitable it not, on the next fair day thereafter.

div3.head: There
div3.p:
pairs of shoes were taken from negro boys March 23d, believed to have been stolen.
Any one that can prove property, and pay for this advertisement, can get them by applying to
div3.closer:
Mrs. Schontarber,
Broad st, 2d door above 2d. mh 26--2t*

div3.head: For hire
div3.p:
--For the balance of the year, a No. 1 Nurse and Chambermaid.
She has a baby about five weeks old. Terms moderate.
Apply to Cashier of Bank of Va.

div3.head: For sale.
div3.p:
--A negro woman about 32 years age, and two girls, one 18 years, another years old. The woman is an excellent cook, washer and ironer.
All speak English and French very well, and understand Spanish and sold for no fault.
Also, a negro man, a good gardener.
They will be sold separately, if desired.
div3.closer:
R F Duhand,
Clay st bet Foushee and Adams sts. mh 24--3t*

div3.p: To the Friends of the Soldiers throughout the Confederacy.--

div4.head:
Quartermaster Gen'ls department,
railroad Bureau,
Richmond, Feb. 20, 1864.
div4.p:
The friends and relatives of soldiers in the Army of Northern Virginia are hereby notified that an arrangement has this day been effected with the Southern Express Company to carry all packages of food and wearing apparel to Richmond.
Va.
To secure the advantages thus obtained through the Express Company, the following instructions must be observed:

Packages must not contain more than one hundred pounds; be well secured and plainly marked, and sent at the expense of the shipper to either of the Soldiers' Relief Associations, which are located as follows:
In North Carolina, at Raleigh; in South Carolina, at Columbia, in Georgia at Augusta; in Alabama, at Montgomery or any other point at which one of these Associations have an office.

The Agents of these Associations will there take charge of them and ship daily by Southern Express Company to the proper Agents of the respective States at Richmond, who will see them distributed to the proper individual owners.

To meet the wishes of the soldiers, and to give them a certain and speedy communication with home, the Southern Express Company has agreed to give this freight preference and everything else; and, in order that no obstacle may occur to the success of so laudable on enterprise, the several railroad companies are hereby requested to render the Express Company such fact will enable it is make this arrangement a complete success.

As the Southern Express Company assumes all responsibility of the transportation of these packages, the Relief Associations are requested to withdraw their Agents who have heretofore noted as travelling messengers.
If the Relief Associations will establish agencies in the rear of other armies, they may enjoy the same privileges hereby accrued to the Army of Northern Virginia.
div4.closer:
F W Sims,
Lieut.-Col. and Quartermaster.
Approved:
A R Lawton,
Quartermaster General

div4.head:
Office Southern Express Company,
Augusta, Ga, Feb. 20, 1864.
div4.p: The Southern Express Company hereby notify the friends and relatives of soldiers in the Army of Northern Virginia and elsewhere that they are prepared to carry out arrangements as announced in the above card, and that then will do all in their power to its requirements.
div4.closer:
James Shuter,
General Sup't and Acting President,
Southern Express Company. fe 27--eod3m
